sops.title: SOP 1: Completing the Square
sops.goal: Convert quadratic from standard form to completed square form
triggers: express in the form (x + p)² + q
steps: Identify coefficient of x²: If it's not 1, factor it out first
Take half of the x coefficient, square it: For x² + bx, take (b/2)²
Add and subtract this value inside: x² + bx + (b/2)² - (b/2)²
Group to form perfect square: (x + b/2)² - (b/2)² + c
Simplify the constant term: Combine constants to get final form (x + p)² + q

pitfalls.text: Forgetting to factor out the coefficient of x² before completing the square

pro_tips: Always write out the add-and-subtract step explicitly: + (b/2)² - (b/2)²
Check your answer by expanding back to verify

sops.title: SOP 2: Graph Sketching (Quadratics)
sops.goal: Sketch the parabola with all key features labeled
steps: Identify the turning point: Use completed square form (x + p)² + q gives turning point (-p, q)
Determine if it opens up or down: Positive coefficient of x² → opens up, Negative → opens down
Find y-intercept: Set x = 0 and calculate y
Find x-intercepts (if they exist): Set y = 0 and solve the quadratic (use formula if needed)
Sketch: Draw smooth U-shape through all labeled points

pitfalls.text: Getting the sign wrong for the turning point coordinates
Forgetting to label all intercepts and the turning point

pro_tips: If completing the square gives (x - a)² + b, turning point is (a, b) not (-a, b)

sops.title: SOP 3: Finding Equation from Graph
sops.goal: Determine the quadratic equation given key features of the graph
triggers: given turning point and another point
steps: Start with completed square form: Use y = a(x - h)² + k where (h, k) is the turning point
Substitute the other given point: Plug in the coordinates to find the value of a
Solve for a: Isolate a in the equation
Write the final equation: Either in completed square form or expand to standard form if required

pitfalls.text: Forgetting to include the coefficient a in front
Sign errors when substituting coordinates with negative values

pro_tips: Always use y = a(x - h)² + k form first, it's faster than y = ax² + bx + c
Verify by checking if the turning point satisfies your final equation
